Award.AwardTitle: Application of Evidence-Centered Design to State Large-Scale Science Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The underlying claim of this proposal is that traditional test development processes have failed to produce science assessments that address high-reasoning levels, are not integrated with learning and formative assessments, and are too costly to implement at scale. It faces the challenge of conceptualizing and developing effective and affordable development processes that result in complex, interactive (e.g., simulations, investigations), valid, and standards-based science tasks that can be incorporated into existing statewide testing systems. In order to address this challenge, the proposal aims at (1) determining ways in which ECD enhances the quality of large-scale, technology-based assessments for middle school grades in key science education strands; (2) implementing resulting procedures in operational state-level test development; (3) evaluating the effectiveness and generalizability of these procedures, and (4) disseminating findings to the assessment community.

The proposal builds on previously funded NSF research projects, such as Principled Assessment Designs for Inquiry?s (PADI), a REC-supported online system, which has developed data structures, representational forms, and software tools for the assessment of science inquiry concepts and skills (e.g., inquiry cycles, model-based reasoning) that allows efficient item development. The proposal also integrates the Evidence-Centered Design (ECD) methodology on which PADI is based. The ECD approach relates the learning to be assessed to an evidence model that specifies the student responses and scores serving as ?evidence of proficiency?. Further, the proposal integrates the Pearson Educational Measurement (PEM) test development infrastructure to create inquiry-based science tasks, and align those with the Minnesota Comprehensive Assessments.

Anticipated products include (a) training materials for intended users, (b) ECD-based processes, (c) data structures and authoring interfaces, (d) exemplar design patterns and science tasks, (e) data analyses of large-scale administration of tasks (previously field- and pilot-tested), and (f) publications in scientific journals. Key questions on quality/validity, efficiency/costs, and technological benefits guide both formative and summative evaluation. Dissemination comprises a technical report series, presentations and workshops at professional organizations? annual meetings, and articles in peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, Application of Evidence-Centered Design to State Large-Scale Science Assessment, is concerned with demonstrating the value of Evidence-Centered Design (ECD) in developing complex technology-based tasks (scenarios and associated items) for hard-to-assess science concepts in the context of Minnesota’s large-scale science assessment and the GED® Science Subtest. This project was dedicated to developing assessment tools, processes, examples, and writer training materials to support the development of scenario-based science assessment tasks. Project work is documented in technical reports, conference presentations, book chapters, and journal articles. A project website provides background on ECD, project activities, and downloadable versions of 13 technical reports. (http://ecd.sri.com.)

The work of this project is based on advances in assessment design, cognitive psychology, STEM research, and technology. The emergence of interactive assessment tasks, multidimensional proficiencies, and the modeling of multi-step problem-solving tasks requires a different language and new representational forms. For these reasons, we rely on the concepts, terms, and representations of ECD to share our ideas. The project provides the assessment community with an example of how a unified perspective—ECD—can improve the efficiency and validity of assessment design and development.

Nine Design Patterns associated with hard-to-assess science concepts in the Minnesota science standards were created collaboratively by team members. Learning how to use the Design Pattern attributes to support the development of scenario-based assessment tasks was a major activity in Years 2 and 3. All project Design Patterns are described in the project’s technical reports.

In Years 4-6, the project focused on the design and development of training materials associated with storyboards and scenario-based items. Three technology-enhanced tools were developed: (1) technology-enhanced Design Patterns (i.e., hyperlinked details, horizontal views), (2) an activation spreadsheet connecting science standards to Design Patterns, and (3) a scenario planning form. Also, the team created a software “wizard” to assist storyboard designers in using Design Patterns to develop storyboards and items. “Wizard” development is documented in a project technical report.

During Years 4 and 5, three professional development training sessions were conducted to train GED® test developers in the use of Design Patterns and PADI. Also, a workshop was held at the 2011 AERA annual meeting. Approximately 40 people attended, including science education researchers, assessment professionals, state education officials, and representatives of international education ministries. Feedback was used to refine the ECD tools and enhance their utility and user-friendliness. Project evaluators collected data on training efforts and the subsequent use of Design Patterns in the test development process. Evaluators used mixed methods, including surveys, interviews, and analysis of generated artifacts. High-level project outcomes are presented below.

  • Ways to Leverage ECD

 

The roles of narrative structures, Design Patterns, and task templates were explored to identify novel ways in which ECD could be leveraged in large-scale assessment development. Simply providing additional information and structures to test developers (e.g., narrative structures, Design Patterns) is insufficient. Scaffolding ECD tools and resources made the ECD-based design process more accessible.
